awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Constitutions and the Political Economy of Health
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to understand whether and how protecting health as a right in a nation's constitution improves the health of its citizens. Currently, just over half of written constitutions in the world include a "right to health" in seemingly enforceable language. Whether this is beneficial to health outcomes and health policy, however, is not clear. Prominent ethicists suggest it should benefit public health policy while many legal experts have voiced skepticism -- yet little empirical evidence is currently available. This project uses a mix of quantitative analysis and qualitative field research to examine the effects of institutionalizing health as a constitutional right. If a right to health does operate to improve health -- expanding the power of civil society, the legal system, and health-related officials to improve health policy and health outcomes -- then it could be a powerful tool to improve the wellbeing of individuals in society. If not, it may problematically distort health policy. This project seeks to build scientific knowledge through interdisciplinary research, addressing these unanswered questions for the fields of law, public health, and political science. While the United States lacks an explicit constitutional right, health policy is increasingly legalized and, with the Affordable Care Act, the role of the state in health and of courts as arbiters is expanding. As such, lessons from this study may provide insights applicable to a U.S. context. In addition, this research may help national security and aid agencies implement more effective global health programs by identifying when, if, and how legal institutions can improve health policymaking. Globally, the average national constitution is significantly rewritten every 20 years, so whether a right to health is meaningful, and what factors make it so, are important pieces of information for constitution drafters and the health policymakers. 

This study sets out to assess, in comparative perspective, the operation and effect of a constitutional right to health as an institution within the political economy health. Bringing insights and tools from political economy to the study of public law can help expand the emerging field of comparative constitutionalism -- in this case bridging the gap between existing normative and doctrinal studies of socioeconomic rights and the large field of empirical research on health and social policy. Adding to scientific knowledge on the production function of population health is also a goal.  This project does so through mixed-methods "nested analysis" in South Africa, India, and Thailand that combines a large-N statistical regression with small-N fieldwork-based case studies. First, the study will construct a global panel dataset with national health, demographic, economic, and constitutional characteristics spanning 40 years and use multilevel regression analysis to examine the empirical relationship globally between a right to health and health outcomes. If the study's hypotheses are correct, there should be observably better health outcomes in countries with a right to health, controlling for the dominant economic, demographic, and political explanations for national wellbeing.  Second, the study will gain causal leverage by seeking evidence directly linking the right to health with pro-health policymaking through field work in South Africa, India, and Thailand. Within-case analysis of interview and archival data will allow "process tracing" of recent health and health-related policymaking to help determine whether the statistical relationship observed in the large-N analysis is causal. Ultimately, data from this project should provide strong evidence about whether and how a constitutional right to health affects public health outcomes -- with implications for health policy, constitution-writing, and legal reform.

por.por_cntn:
This project was designed to explore whether the impact of including health as a right in national constitutions. The United States does not have a constitutional right to health and skepticism about such rights is widespread. But outside the United States it has become increasingly common to include a “right to health” in written constitutions. Does this matter for public health? Should the United States consider enacting such enforceable health rights—if not through constitutional amendment then through legislative means?

 

Ethicists, theorists, activists, and constitution writers have argued that the right to health provides a critical framework for health policy and should improve population health. There are many skeptics, however, who argue that health is not best understood through a rights-based framework. Some argue it will simply have no effect—because courts have little power over health and social factors matter far more. Others worry constitutionalizing health may have a negative effect—emphasizing the interests of a small number over good, balanced public health policymaking. This project was designed to adjudicate empirically between these hypotheses.

 

Method: A “nested analysis” with two levels: First a quantitative study used 40 years of global health data and a coding of national constitutions to test whether there was any effect of this right.  Using a multilevel time series regression on data from 1970-2010, with control variables for the major explanations for variation in mortality within the economics and social determinants of health literature and measures of democracy the effect of a right to health was statistically estimated.  At a second level, a qualitative study sought to test these findings to reveal the mechanisms at work—if there is an effect, can we trace it through the various health policy processes to show that a right to health is actually causal? Field work was conducted in South Africa, India, and Thailand, where over 165 interviews were completed and newspaper and other document archives were reviewed.  

 

Findings: Clear and strong evidence of a positive effect of the right to health.

 

First, statistical analysis shows that that countries with a right to health have better health outcomes—in particular lower child mortality rates, a leading indicator of overall wellbeing. This finding holds even controlling for the dominant explanations for cross-national variation in health found in the public health and social science literature. Not surprisingly, the effect is small compared to, for example, national income or women’s education, which together account for much of the state and societal capacity to address health. But it is notable that the effect is the equivalent of a major change in democracy score—as large as going from a country like Iran to one like Switzerland or Costa Rica.

 

Secondly, clear evidence was gathered that the right to health is actually causal: that constitutionalization has a direct effect on health policy; and that the right to health acts independently of other factors such as democracy. Our qualitative data shows that constitutionalizing health creates a more health-conducive institutional context. It is not only, or even primarily, a story about court orders—which some see as anti-democratic. Instead, where a right to health is institutionalized, the process of health policymaking is different. The right to health acts as a policy anchor: for modern governments buffeted by countervailing pressures, constitutional rights can focus political power and attention to improve health policy. It acts through three mechanisms: 1) Unblocking policy change by deconstructing policy monopolies: Even in strong democracies, complex issues in health policy are delegated to sub-systems of bureaucrats, experts, and interest groups that exclude outsiders and defend the status quo. Anchoring health in the constitution gives the opportunity to “expand the conflict” by shifting some questions to courts and other venues, which opens room for policy change. 2) Improving the bargaining endowments of key actors: Rights mobilization does not end bargaining over policy issues but puts a particular set of tools at the disposal of those inside and outside the state seeking to spur health-enhancing policy change. Discovery can bring out information; subpoenas can call individual policymakers to account; reputational risk posed by litigation can raise the incentives for action; and public/media narratives can legitimate change—all of which affects bargaining outside the courtroom, regardless of any court order. 3) Providing “reasons for action”: Anchored in the core national political bargain, constitutional health rights provide a discourse with the power to undermine closed policy monopolies while enhancing the legitimacy of policy options focused on action over inaction.

 

Conclusion: Together this evidence suggests that a right to health, embodied in law, can have a positive effect on health. Political science, law, and public health scholars should consider the significant rights contexts in future work on the institutions of development. Meanwhile, legislators, public health policymakers, and others might be well served to consider expanding rights in contexts such as the U.S. to improve wellbeing.
